name: NPR
text:
A DOJ investigation found that corrections officers in Alabama men's prisons frequently use excessive, and at times, deadly force in violation of inmates' constitutional rights in 12 out of 13 prisons reviewed.
https://t.co/LpjO4JEshW

name: NPR
text: TikTok is seeking ways to distance itself from its Chinese parent company as the White House considers economic sanctions to cut off the popular app from U.S. users. https://t.co/hJjpjUPa6x

name: NPR
text:
Southwest and American Airlines will require all customers over the age of 2 to wear masks on board and at airports ‚Äî no exceptions. 

The airlines say, as of next week, people who don't comply will not be allowed to fly.
https://t.co/KZUzezfGUV

name: NPR
text:
Disney says it has pushed back or canceled the release dates of 17 films ‚Äî including the live-action remake of "Mulan," three "Star Wars" pictures and four "Avatar" sequels.
https://t.co/S4IvskWG8B

name: NPR
text:
President Trump acknowledged that public schools should delay reopening in coronavirus hotspots ‚Äî but said they should open fully if they want to receive tens of billions of dollars in new federal aid.
https://t.co/DMYO7R68Ra

name: NPR
text:
NEW: A federal judge has temporarily barred federal officers in Portland from arresting, threatening to arrest or using force against anyone they "reasonably should know" is a legal observer or journalist documenting daily protests. (@OPB)
https://t.co/8w77dpeA3f

name: NPR
text:
Venezuelans trapped in Ecuador by COVID-19 are determined to make the trip back ‚Äî on foot if they have to. 

üîäThe story of their return and the 53-year-old civil servant leading one group home, from @Roughly @elhilopodcast + @radioambulante. 
https://t.co/cJIq2FfiPo

name: NPR
text:
There have been just 11 COVID-19 deaths in Jordan. 

‚ÄúWe did everything we can to make sure our children, our elderly, our refugees ‚Äî you know, the haves and the have-nots ‚Äî are protected,‚Äù says the prime minister.  https://t.co/iOnmiLFzTe

name: NPR
text:
The body of civil rights icon John Lewis will lie in state at the U.S. Capitol next week.

The congressman's family is urging non-locals to pay tribute virtually, instead of traveling to Washington, D.C., because of the pandemic.
https://t.co/VMjBGua7d3

name: NPR
text:
Dr. Louis Tran went to New York to aid ICUs grappling with COVID-19. Now, he's fighting the virus in California.

"It's difficult when you're just being bombarded," he says.  "That's the calling of emergency medicine and we answer the call 24/7."
https://t.co/BjtylNzHzo

name: NPR
text:
Erika James, the first woman and first Black person to lead the Wharton School, says the business world has the ability and should create a more diverse work environment, but it hasn't "prioritized it."
https://t.co/dp4B6azrCX

name: NPR
text:
"It was a false flag operation." 

A Turkish admiral and some of his fellow officers say they are convinced President Erdogan staged a 2016 coup attempt in an effort to expand power, though analysts cast doubt that Erdogan was behind it.
https://t.co/GnvCKwIGNz

name: NPR
text:
For years, refugees seeking asylum at the Canadian border have been turned back because they crossed through another country that offers human rights protections.

But now a judge has ruled the U.S. treatment of the refugees violates human rights.
https://t.co/KrXmgHjhT6

name: NPR
text:
Researchers analyzed the data from every study on the protective effect of masks. 

Their bottom-line estimate: If 95% of people wear cloth masks, it reduces transmission by at least 30%.

With this example, here's what happens over seven 5-day cycles üëá
https://t.co/wVSl0NX4nP https://t.co/dVF4Tyt3CO

name: NPR
text: China's Foreign Ministry has ordered the closure of the U.S. consulate in Chengdu. The move is in apparent retaliation to a U.S. order to close the Chinese consulate in Houston earlier this week. https://t.co/K2STTw0gjj

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. Space Force has accused Russia of testing an anti-satellite weapon from one of its satellites in orbit ‚Äî marking the first time the military has publicly charged Moscow with carrying out a space-based weapons test.
https://t.co/2boUGY2y4N

name: NPR
text:
In 1929, the President of Mexico gave Charles Lindbergh a painting by artist Alfredo Ramos Mart√≠nez. 

Now, almost a century after Mart√≠nez painted the "Flores Mexicanas," it was seen in public for just the second time.
https://t.co/LzY7yxSRO8

name: NPR
text:
The real star of Netflix's ‚ÄúFloor Is Lava‚Äù ‚Äî is the lava. 

The magma is the result of months of work by Hollywood's top slime manufacturers. (Fun fact: It smells like bubble gum.) https://t.co/3eunoTfg0W

name: NPR
text: President Trump's deployment federal forces in U.S. cities, answerable only to him, "is manifestly unconstitutional," Harvard law professor Laurence Tribe writes for @WBUR. "This is not mere disregard for the rule of law -- this is outright disdain." https://t.co/RNY2AhaKuI

name: NPR
text: A federal judge issued a temporary restraining order barring federal agents in Portland from arresting or using force against journalists and observers. The order details several examples of journalists being fired upon, pepper sprayed and hit with batons. https://t.co/WmDioXVOCH

name: NPR
text: To protect its 61,000 students and staff this fall, the University of Illinois has developed its own saliva test for the new coronavirus -- and plans to analyze up to 10,000 of them a day. @ILNewsroom https://t.co/rlXZHnnYO5

name: NPR
text: It's estimated that as many as 20% of restaurants in the U.S. might not make it ‚Äî especially when the weather gets colder and many places have to close patios and outdoor seating. https://t.co/x92rnNQGdm

name: NPR
text:
The @WatkinsFamHour's latest album, "Brother Sister," is the first album that siblings Sean and Sara have written as a duo in their 30-plus year career.
https://t.co/hLb4kz2P0T

name: NPR
text: Taylor Swift's surprise new album ‚Äì announced just 16 hours before its release ‚Äì¬†is officially available to stream. https://t.co/yvqPVu2kat

name: NPR
text:
Two Seattle baristas became best friends and led the specialty coffee movement in the U.S. ‚Äî by founding @LaColombeCoffee.

üîäThe journey of Todd Carmichael and J.P. Iberti is this week's @HowIBuiltThis: https://t.co/pUjL8pqAIg

name: NPR
text:
Before you head out car camping, research:

üèî where you want to go
üõ∂ what activities you want to do during the day
‚õ∫ where you're going to sleep
üß¶ what to pack
‚ôø accessibility
üìç who inhabited the land before you (try the @nativelandnet app!)
https://t.co/vRK8UjyueB

name: NPR
text:
Images of federal officers in camo making arrests on Portland's streets have alarmed critics who think the president is using them to trample civil liberties and paint himself as a law-in-order candidate ahead of November.
https://t.co/hhR2GXa8Rr

name: NPR
text:
A DOJ report says the use of batons, chemical spray and physical force by Alabama prison staff often resulted in serious inmate injuries.

In one fatal incident, the force used against an inmate caused "extensive bleeding in multiple parts of his brain."
https://t.co/xeXT1eDgDI

name: NPR
text:
American military officers privately say that a number of arrested Turkish officers they worked closely with were clearly not culpable in the 2016 coup attempt in Turkey ‚Äî but were suspect because they either worked for NATO or spent time in the US.
https://t.co/0XZdSjlZz1

name: NPR
text:
The White House is lifting a months-long ban on New York state residents from taking part in the Trusted Traveler Program ‚Äî after Homeland Security admitted that it made false statements responding to a lawsuit New York brought over the issue.
https://t.co/D32hlNOfS7

name: NPR
text:
Medical experts warn that case fatality rate for COVID-19 is a moving target‚Äî and an unreliable and misleading metric for communicating about the pandemic.

But that hasn't stopped President Trump from boasting about it.
https://t.co/n2V79EQfdN

name: NPR
text:
A growing number of researchers say until there's an effective coronavirus vaccine in widespread use, we will never achieve herd immunity.

"It's going to be with us probably forever at this point," one expert says. "It's how we decide to live with it."
https://t.co/z9be8U7d8t

name: NPR
text:
Authorities in Thailand have announced they're dropping all charges against the heir to the Red Bull fortune, stemming from a hit-and-run that killed a Bangkok police officer in 2012.
https://t.co/3ALDxu2bza

name: NPR
text:
Susan Rice, former U.N. ambassador and national security adviser, is said to be getting serious consideration from the Biden campaign.

She's never held elected office ‚Äî but no other potential running mate matches her foreign policy experience.
https://t.co/1irCa2RnkM

name: NPR
text:
As zoos across the country start to reopen, one curator says certain animals seem to have missed having people around ‚Äî but not all of them.

"We haven't seen the cats get super excited about seeing people," he says. "But that's honestly to be expected."
https://t.co/vXoPLqcsxS

name: NPR
text:
A new survey finds that 40% of LGBTQ young people in the U.S. have considered suicide in the past year.

But those "who have an accepting adult in their lives were 40% less likely to attempt suicide," says the CEO of The Trevor Project.
https://t.co/7XiM7XQQqP

name: NPR
NPR
text:
More than 25 million Americans have been receiving federal unemployment benefits during the pandemic. But that money stops this weekend.

Housing advocates are warning that the U.S. could see a "tsunami" of evictions if Congress doesn't act.
https://t.co/garZAUVhEQ

name: NPR
text:
A DOJ report finds the use of batons, chemical spray and physical force by Alabama prison staff often resulted in serious inmate injuries.

In one fatal incident, the force used against an inmate caused "extensive bleeding in multiple parts of his brain."
https://t.co/k5jeUMpouI

name: NPR
text:
A new survey of over 40,000 LGBTQ young people in the U.S. finds that:

‚Ä¢ 40% have considered suicide in the last year
‚Ä¢ 86% say recent politics have negatively impacted them
‚Ä¢ 1 in 3 reported being physically threatened or harmed due to their identity
https://t.co/uivBCWYKPi

name: NPR
text:
It's easy to get mad when we see people not following public health guidelines. But Harvard epidemiologist Julia Marcus says public shaming can end up being the opposite of productive.

She explains why on this episode of #NPRShortWave:  
 https://t.co/9BfVCHzhoF
